posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-Nine: Picturing the Subway in 1970s New York
posts.text: In this episode Julie Golia and Kim Phillips-Fein explored a collection of evocative photographs of the New York City subway system in the 1970s by Alen MacWeeney, discussing what the images reveal about the city during a decade of crisis and transformation.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode 38: The Mapleson Cylinders, Listening to a Treasure
posts.text: In this episode, Jonathan Hiam and Jon Samuels analyzed the Mapleson Cylinders and discussed the preservation and restoration of the many historical audio formats held by NYPL.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-Seven: Recovering Frances Burney's Cecilia
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Carolyn Vegan and Hilary Havens of the University of Tennessee explored the manuscripts of 18th-century English novelist Frances Burney.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-Six: Augusta Savage's "Lift Every Voice and Sing," A Treasure of Liberation
posts.text: In this episode, Doc Chatters honored the work and legacies of two Black female artists, a sculptor and a poet, across generations.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-Five: Photographing Migration and Ethnicity at Ellis Island
posts.text: In this episode Bogdan Horbal of NYPL and Smoki Musaraj of Ohio University, discussed photographer Lewis Wickes Hine's celebration of ethnic and cultural diversity as a manifesto against rising prejudice and discrimination against specific groups of immigrants.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-Four: Reframing Columbia Eneutseak, Decentering the Imperialist Gaze
posts.text: In this episode, Doc Chat paid homage to a remarkable Inuit performer and considered how she appealed to and defied stereotypes as an Indigenous woman in modern American society.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-Three: The 1811 Plan for Manhattan, a Treasure of the New York Public Library
posts.text: In Episode Thirty-Three, NYPL’s Sara Spink and Ian Fowler discussed the 1811 Commissioners’ Map and Survey of Manhattan Island, featured in the Library’s newly opened The Polonsky Exhibition of The New York Public Library’s Treasures.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-Two: Identity, Anti-Bias Practices, and the Library Catalog
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Paloma Celis Carbajal and Jelicia Jimenez were joined by Bronwen Maxson of the University of Oregon to discuss how issues of identity, particularly as relates to immigrant communities in the U.S., have shaped discovery tools such as library catalogs in far-reaching ways. They also examined the role of student activism in catalyzing change.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty-One: Race and Slavery's Pandemic Legacies
posts.text: In this episode, historians Michelle Commander and Christopher Willoughby discussed the racialization of disease in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, analyzing a 1802 medical advice manual for treating enslaved people in the Caribbean and a 1799 pamphlet that argues that blackness (skin color) is a form of leprosy.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirty: Researching Problematic Content in Pop Culture History
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Andy McCarthy and author and journalist Mark Harris considered what it means to analyze moments in history that do not align with the social ethics, cultural standards, and popular beliefs of the current moment.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-Nine: Pre-Revolutionary Russia Through Bolshevik Eyes
posts.text: In this episode NYPL's Bogdan Horbal and Samuel Casper of Hunter College delved into Dmitrii Moor's 1919 propaganda poster Sud narodnyi (The People's Court). They offered a close analysis of the evocative imagery in the print, which is a satirical procession depicting the various strata of late Imperial Russian society swept away by the Revolutions of 1917.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-Six: Pandemic Visions in Newspapers and Literature from Mexico
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Paloma Celis Carbajal and Óscar A. Pérez, Assistant Professor of Spanish at Skidmore College, explored cultural expressions in Mexico during the influenza pandemics of 1918 and 2009 through newspapers and other digitized materials.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-Seven: Exploring 1930s New York City Through Tenement Photography
posts.text: In Episode Twenty-Seven, NYPL's Carmen Nigro and Annie Polland, President of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, examined photos taken by inspectors of the New York City Tenement House Department and discussed reform, regulation, and social conditions in Depression-era NYC.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-Five: History in the (Zine) Making
posts.text: In this episode, Bridgett Pride and Kadiatou Tubman of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture discussed ways that they have used zines and zine-making projects to help students of all ages explore historical research, express their creativity, and envision themselves as historians.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-Four: Seeing Beethoven
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Bob Kosovsky and Fredric Fehleisen of The Juilliard School discussed an early 19th-century portrait of Ludwig van Beethoven now owned by the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-Three: Manuscripts of Eminent Women
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL’s Liz Denlinger and Professor Michelle Levy of Simon Fraser University analyzed an album of letters by "Eminent Women," collected by a London librarian and self-professed sufferer of “autographic mania,” William Upcott.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-Two: Place-Based History on NYC's Broadway
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Gregory Stall and Fran Leadon, Associate Professor of Architecture at City College, analyzed maps and menus that reveal the multilayered history of Broadway, with a focus on the transformation of the Upper West Side.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty-One: Slavery and Capitalism in the Archives
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Matt Knutzen and NYU Professor Tom Augst probed the archives of Brown Brothers & Company and revealed the hands-on role that the financial firm played in managing one Southern plantation.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twenty: Aerial Photography in Focus
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL’s Ian Fowler and Elizabeth Cronin revealed the cultural and technological origins of aerial photography, analyzed several examples, and provided historical context for its use in exploration, the military, mapmaking, and more.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Nineteen: Naming Pictures
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Jessica Cline and photographer, publisher, and Pratt Institute photography professor Peter Kayafas discussed the history and scope of the Picture Collection, analyzing the concept of subjectivity in the subject headings assigned to images and considering how description shapes representation and creates trust in the work of librarians.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Eighteen: Fancy for Feathers and the Fight to Save Birds
posts.text: On March 4, 2021, Doc Chat kicked off Women's History Month by examining the intersection of gender, conservation, activism, fashion, and birds—yes, birds!—in the early 20th century.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Seventeen: A Blend of East and West in Filipiniana Clothing
posts.text: In this episode, Miguel Rosales of NYPL and costume designer Raven Ong of Central Connecticut State University, analyzed images of Filipiniana dress in the context of the Philippines' colonial past and discussed the ways in which clothing influences the weaving of a national narrative.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Sixteen: Teaching the #Syllabus
posts.text: In this episode, the Schomburg Center's Zakiya Collier and Dr. Yarimar Bonilla of Hunter College and CUNY Graduate Center explored Schomburg's #Syllabi web archive collection and the Puerto Rico Syllabus, and discussed erasure and underrepresentation in academia, digital protest, and ways of deploying Hashtag Syllabi in the classroom.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Fifteen: Exploitative Depictions of the Americas
posts.text: This week NYPL's Ian Fowler and Camilla Townsend, Distinguished Professor of History at Rutgers University, analyzed John Ogilby's 1671 atlas of the Americas that depicted Indigenous peoples and lands along with fantastic elements like fictional beasts.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Fourteen: Exploring the Black Alternative Press of the 1960s and 1970s
posts.text: In this episode we're joined by Amaka Okechukwu, professor of sociology at George Mason University, to analyze excerpts from 'Black Dialogue' and discuss the historical context in which the magazine was written, published, and circulated.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Thirteen: Chinese Railroad Workers in Stereoscopic Photography
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL's Zulay Chang and public historian Richard Cheu analyzed several 19th-century photographs related to the construction and completion of the transcontinental railroad.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Twelve: Putting Protest Photography Under the Lens
posts.text: In the final Doc Chat of the year, we dug into the stories behind photographs of radical demonstrations in early 20th-century New York City.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Eleven: Modernism and Women Photographers
posts.text: On the most recent episode of Doc Chat we explored the intersection of gender and modernism in early 20th-century photography. NYPL's Elizabeth Cronin and Andrea Nelson of the National Gallery of Art discussed the little known histories of two female photographers: Thérèse Bonney and Elizabeth Buehrmann.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Ten: Along Brooklyn's Industrialdoc Waterfront
posts.text: In this episode, NYPL curators Ian Fowler and Julie Golia analyzed maps, illustrations, and other primary sources from NYPL’s collections to look at the transformation of Brooklyn’s waterfront economy and built environment

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Seven: Listening to and Reading Holocaust Testimony
posts.text: Doc Chatters explored themes of memory, trauma, and resilience through the oral history of one Holocaust survivor.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Eight: The Making of a Malcolm X Speech
posts.text: A behind-the-scenes glimpse into the making of one of Malcolm X's most iconic—and misunderstood—speeches, "The Ballot or the Bullet".

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Six: Visions of Modernity at the 1939 New York World's Fair
posts.text: The 1939 New York World's Fair promised a view of the "World of Tomorrow" through its dazzling displays of up-to-the-minute cultural and technological advancements. The fair's iconic posters were the topic of the most recent episode of Doc Chat—find a recording of the event below as well as links to related resources to explore.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Five: Poetry and Revolution on the Lower East Side
posts.text: Revolution was in the air on October 8, 2020, when the Doc Chat community traveled back in time to New York City in the 1960s to learn about the vibrant radical literary culture of the Lower East Side.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Four: Printing the Boston Massacre
posts.text: A spirited conversation about a professional rivalry between two colonial printers, and what it can tell us about the American Revolution, and early American print culture.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Three: Abolitionism in Black and White?
posts.text: NYPL’s Julie Golia and Bronx Community College Professor and public historian Prithi Kanakamedala discussed one anti-slavery illustration and what it can tell us about the racial politics of abolitionism.

posts.title: Doc Chat Episode Two: "Militant" Maude Malone
posts.text: NYPL's Susan Kriete and Cara Dellatte used two evocative photos to piece together the life of "Militant" Maude Malone, who was not only a feminist and activist, but also a NYPL Librarian.

posts.title: We Want to Hear Your Pandemic Story
posts.text: We are proud to announce Pandemic Diaries, a new initiative that invites you to submit audio recordings of yourself or your loved ones telling personal stories about life during the era of COVID-19.

posts.title: Attention Primary Source Lovers: Introducing Doc Chat
posts.text: A new program series for teachers, scholars, researchers, librarians, students, and all-around primary source lovers.

posts.title: Teaching American History With NYPL Digital Collections: Revolutionary New York
posts.text: The NYPL has a bevy of resources to support students and educators on this journey.

posts.title: Teaching American History With NYPL Digital Collections: Childhood in America
posts.text: Understanding that they, as young people, are historical actors and that their lives are worthy of scholarly analysis can be a profoundly empowering experience.

posts.title: Feeling Nostalgia for the Subway? These Photos Might Help
posts.text: Our Digital Collections are rich with subway material including a collection of photographs by Alen MacWeeney that capture the quirkiness, diversity, and grittiness of late 1970s New York.

posts.title: Teaching American History With NYPL Digital Collections: Reconstruction
posts.text: Explore our rich online-accessible resources that can help teachers tackle the Reconstruction era.
